components.name: Botón Standard
components.description: It is perfect for the most important actions in your design. Easy to use and customize.

cases.title: Primary Actions
cases.description: Use this button for the main actions you want users to take, such as submitting a form, saving changes, or starting a process.

examples.description: The “Submit” button on a contact form, where users send their information.
The “Save” button in a settings panel, allowing users to save their preferences.

cases.title: Call to Action
cases.description: It’s ideal for highlighting key actions on a page.

examples.description: A “Get Started” button on a landing page to encourage sign-ups.
A “Buy Now” button on a product page, prompting users to make a purchase.

cases.title: Navigation
cases.description: Can be used as a navigation element to guide users through your site or app.

examples.description: A “Next” button in a multi-step form or survey.
A “Learn More” button that takes users to additional information or resources.

highlights.description: The button stands out and directs users’ attention to the action they need to take.
Provides a clear and easy way for users to interact with your design.
Easily customizable to match the look and feel of your project.

hints.description: Bring the button into your design by dragging it from the components panel.
Double-click on the button to change the text. Make it something action-oriented, like “Submit” or “Learn More.”
Use the properties panel to adjust the button’s size, color, and font to fit your design.
Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.
Adjust the overall size of the button to fit different contexts within your design. Options include Small, Medium, and Large.
The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

hints.description: is the foundational structure of the button, providing core layout properties that define its appearance.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

hints.description: is a nested element within the button, managing the text and icons to ensure clear, readable labels.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

principles.description: Ensure the button color contrasts with the background for better visibility.

examples.description: A bright blue button on a white background.

principles.description: Place buttons in consistent locations to improve user familiarity and ease of use.

examples.description: Place “Submit” buttons at the bottom of forms.

principles.description: Use action-oriented and concise text for button labels.

examples.description: Instead of “Click Here,” use “Download Report.”

principles.description: Ensure buttons are large enough to be easily tapped or clicked, especially on mobile devices.

tips.description: Follow accessibility guidelines for minimum button size.

hints.description: Combine with input fields to create a complete form.

examples.description: Use a “Submit” button with text fields for a contact form.

hints.description: Use buttons within cards or lists to enable actions on those items.

examples.description: An “Add to Cart” button on a product card.

hints.description: Include buttons in navigation bars for actions like “Sign Up” or “Log In.”

examples.description: A “Sign Up” button in the top navigation bar of a landing page.

examples.description: The “Submit” button on a contact form, where users send their information.
The “Save” button in a settings panel, allowing users to save their preferences.

cases.title: Call to Action
cases.description: It’s ideal for highlighting key actions on a page.

examples.description: A “Get Started” button on a landing page to encourage sign-ups.
A “Buy Now” button on a product page, prompting users to make a purchase.

cases.title: Navigation
cases.description: Can be used as a navigation element to guide users through your site or app.

examples.description: A “Next” button in a multi-step form or survey.
A “Learn More” button that takes users to additional information or resources.

highlights.description: The button stands out and directs users’ attention to the action they need to take.
Provides a clear and easy way for users to interact with your design.
Easily customizable to match the look and feel of your project.

hints.description: Bring the button into your design by dragging it from the components panel.
Double-click on the button to change the text. Make it something action-oriented, like “Submit” or “Learn More.”
Use the properties panel to adjust the button’s size, color, and font to fit your design.
Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.
Adjust the overall size of the button to fit different contexts within your design. Options include Small, Medium, and Large.
The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

hints.description: is the foundational structure of the button, providing core layout properties that define its appearance.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

hints.description: is a nested element within the button, managing the text and icons to ensure clear, readable labels.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.

principles.description: Ensure the button color contrasts with the background for better visibility.

examples.description: A bright blue button on a white background.

principles.description: Place buttons in consistent locations to improve user familiarity and ease of use.

examples.description: Place “Submit” buttons at the bottom of forms.

principles.description: Use action-oriented and concise text for button labels.

examples.description: Instead of “Click Here,” use “Download Report.”

principles.description: Ensure buttons are large enough to be easily tapped or clicked, especially on mobile devices.

tips.description: Follow accessibility guidelines for minimum button size.

hints.description: Combine with input fields to create a complete form.

examples.description: Use a “Submit” button with text fields for a contact form.

hints.description: Use buttons within cards or lists to enable actions on those items.

examples.description: An “Add to Cart” button on a product card.

hints.description: Include buttons in navigation bars for actions like “Sign Up” or “Log In.”

examples.description: A “Sign Up” button in the top navigation bar of a landing page.

cases.title: Call to Action
cases.description: It’s ideal for highlighting key actions on a page.

examples.description: A “Get Started” button on a landing page to encourage sign-ups.
A “Buy Now” button on a product page, prompting users to make a purchase.

cases.description: Can be used as a navigation element to guide users through your site or app.

examples.description: A “Next” button in a multi-step form or survey.
A “Learn More” button that takes users to additional information or resources.

highlights.description: The button stands out and directs users’ attention to the action they need to take.
Provides a clear and easy way for users to interact with your design.
Easily customizable to match the look and feel of your project.

hints.description: Bring the button into your design by dragging it from the components panel.
Double-click on the button to change the text. Make it something action-oriented, like “Submit” or “Learn More.”
Use the properties panel to adjust the button’s size, color, and font to fit your design.
Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.
Adjust the overall size of the button to fit different contexts within your design. Options include Small, Medium, and Large.
The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

highlights.description: The button stands out and directs users’ attention to the action they need to take.
Provides a clear and easy way for users to interact with your design.
Easily customizable to match the look and feel of your project.

hints.description: Bring the button into your design by dragging it from the components panel.
Double-click on the button to change the text. Make it something action-oriented, like “Submit” or “Learn More.”
Use the properties panel to adjust the button’s size, color, and font to fit your design.
Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.
Adjust the overall size of the button to fit different contexts within your design. Options include Small, Medium, and Large.
The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

examples.description: A “Get Started” button on a landing page to encourage sign-ups.
A “Buy Now” button on a product page, prompting users to make a purchase.

cases.title: Navigation
cases.description: Can be used as a navigation element to guide users through your site or app.

examples.description: A “Next” button in a multi-step form or survey.
A “Learn More” button that takes users to additional information or resources.

highlights.description: The button stands out and directs users’ attention to the action they need to take.
Provides a clear and easy way for users to interact with your design.
Easily customizable to match the look and feel of your project.

hints.description: Bring the button into your design by dragging it from the components panel.
Double-click on the button to change the text. Make it something action-oriented, like “Submit” or “Learn More.”
Use the properties panel to adjust the button’s size, color, and font to fit your design.
Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.
Adjust the overall size of the button to fit different contexts within your design. Options include Small, Medium, and Large.
The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

hints.description: is the foundational structure of the button, providing core layout properties that define its appearance.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.

hints.description: is a nested element within the button, managing the text and icons to ensure clear, readable labels.

principles.description: Ensure the button color contrasts with the background for better visibility.

examples.description: A bright blue button on a white background.

principles.description: Place buttons in consistent locations to improve user familiarity and ease of use.

examples.description: Place “Submit” buttons at the bottom of forms.

principles.description: Use action-oriented and concise text for button labels.

examples.description: Instead of “Click Here,” use “Download Report.”

principles.description: Ensure buttons are large enough to be easily tapped or clicked, especially on mobile devices.

tips.description: Follow accessibility guidelines for minimum button size.

hints.description: Combine with input fields to create a complete form.

examples.description: Use a “Submit” button with text fields for a contact form.

hints.description: Use buttons within cards or lists to enable actions on those items.

examples.description: An “Add to Cart” button on a product card.

hints.description: Include buttons in navigation bars for actions like “Sign Up” or “Log In.”

examples.description: A “Sign Up” button in the top navigation bar of a landing page.

Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.

The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

A “Learn More” button that takes users to additional information or resources.

highlights.description: The button stands out and directs users’ attention to the action they need to take.
Provides a clear and easy way for users to interact with your design.
Easily customizable to match the look and feel of your project.

hints.description: Bring the button into your design by dragging it from the components panel.
Double-click on the button to change the text. Make it something action-oriented, like “Submit” or “Learn More.”
Use the properties panel to adjust the button’s size, color, and font to fit your design.
Change the position of icons to be either leading or trailing, or remove them entirely.
Adjust the overall size of the button to fit different contexts within your design. Options include Small, Medium, and Large.
The button adjusts its width based on the content it holds.
The button stretches to fill the width of its container, ensuring a responsive design.

table.description: The state of the button, indicating its interaction state.
The style type of the button, defining its visual importance.
The size of the button, making it adaptable to different contexts.
Toggle the background of the button.
The text displayed on the button.
Swap icons to enhance the button’s meaning.
